key_points: Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III plans to request a waiver from President Joe Biden by mid-September to make COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for service members.
Over 73 percent of active duty personnel have already received at least one shot of the COVID-19 vaccines.
President Biden expressed strong support for making COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for service members, emphasizing their safety and efficacy.
The Department of Defense (DoD) is preparing to add the COVID-19 vaccine to the list of required vaccinations for service members.
Full approval of the vaccines by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) could accelerate the process.
The implementation plan for vaccinating the rest of the active and reserve components is underway.
The Pentagon assures there is no shortage of vaccines and availability will not be a limiting factor.
Pentagon Press Secretary John F. Kirby highlighted the importance of service members getting vaccinated as soon as possible.
The effort reflects a commitment to maintaining the health of service members and operational readiness.
If mandatory vaccination becomes a requirement, the department is prepared to implement this regimen.
spokespersons: Lloyd J. Austin III (Secretary of Defense)
